user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetID:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetID(void)
{
    int32 IdBuf;

    /* always delegate to low-level API */
    if (OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(&IdBuf) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return a hardcoded value on failure */
        return -1;
    }

    return IdBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetID:
int32 OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(int32 *IdBuf)
{
    /* gethostid() has no failure modes */
    *IdBuf = gethostid();
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C Rule 21.17 concerns use of functions from <string.h> (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) and ensuring they do not access beyond the bounds of the objects passed. The provided target function OS_NetworkGetID and its implementation OS_NetworkGetID_Impl do not call any of those string handling functions or any memory copy/concatenation/string length functions. The only pointer usage is passing the address of a stack int32 (IdBuf) into OS_NetworkGetID_Impl, which assigns a scalar via *IdBuf = gethostid(); — this is a single scalar write, not an array/buffer operation, so there is no risk of out-of-bounds access related to string.h functions. The additional definitions (OS_SUCCESS macro and typedef for int32) likewise contain no string.h usage. Therefore there are no fragments in the supplied code relevant to Rule 21.17 that require further investigation.
